Fig. 1 TEM images and particle size histograms of (a) Pt–Sn/SiO2_773 K O2, (b) Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K O2, (c) Pt/SiO2_1073 K N2, (d) Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2, (e) Pt/SiO2_1073 K H2, and (f) Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2. Fig. 2 XRD patterns of (a) Pt–Sn/SiO2_773 K, (b) Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K, (c) Pt/SiO2_773 K, and (d) Pt/SiO2_1073 K treated under (A) oxidative, (B) inert, and (C) reductive atmospheres. Fig. 3 (A) Sn K-edge XANES spectra and (B) Fourier transforms of k 3-weighted EXAFS oscillations for (a) Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K O2, (b) Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2, (c) Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2, (d) Sn foil and (e) SnO2 (×1/2). Fig. 4 (A) Pt L3-edge XANES spectra and (B) variations in unfilled d-states for Pt foil and different catalyst samples. Inset: Enlargement of peaks from Pt L3-edge XANES white line. Fig. 5 Selected DRIFT spectra of CO adsorbed on (A) Pt/SiO2_773 K H2, (B) Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2,(C) Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2, and (D) Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K O2. Fig. 6 Initial conversion of propane (TOS = 10 min) on (A) Pt/SiO2 and (B) Pt–Sn/SiO2 treated under different atmospheres at low (773 K) and high (1073 K) temperatures. Reaction conditions: catalyst weight, 50 mg; reaction temperature, 773 K/1073 K; total flow rate, 100 mL/min; P(C3H8) = 20.3 kPa, P(N2) = 81.0 kPa; GHSV ≈ 22,000 h−1. Fig. 7 Catalytic performance of Pt–Sn/SiO2 catalysts treated under different atmospheres at 1073 K in the dehydrogenation of (A) propane and (B) n-butane. Reaction conditions: catalyst weight, 50 mg; reaction temperature, 773 K for (A), 823 K for (B); total flow rate, 100 mL/min; P(C3H8 or n-C4H10) = 20.3 kPa, P(N2) = 81.0 kPa; GHSV ≈ 22,000 h−1. Fig. 8 Temperature dependence of (A) 1,3-C4H6 and (B) alkenes (1,3-C4H6 and C4H8) formation on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 and Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 (20.3 kPa C4H10; 25 mg catalyst). Elements Strategy Initiative for Catalysts & Batteries Kyoto University 1-30 Goryo-Ohara Nishikyo-ku Kyoto 615-8245 Japan Graphical abstract The dehydrogenation of lower alkanes was investigated on Pt–Sn/SiO2 catalysts prepared by impregnation with different thermal treatments. The treatment atmosphere played an important role in both the catalytic performance and the catalyst structure. An ensemble containing several adjacent Pt and Sn atoms from Pt–SnO2 or Pt–Sn alloy nanoparticles acts as the active site for dehydrogenation of lower alkanes, which can be respectively induced by treatment in an inert atmosphere (N2) or reductive atmosphere (H2) at high temperature. The addition of tin (Sn) is commonly used as a design strategy for catalyst optimization of platinum-based catalysts. The mechanistic understanding of this class of systems is, however, obscured by the structural complexity. Herein, a series of catalyst characterization techniques including X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) and in-situ CO diffuse reflectance infrared fourier transform spectroscopy (CO-DRIFTS) were utilized to study the catalyst structure. It was found that the structure and catalytic properties are closely related with the interaction between Pt and SnO2 (specifically the Pt-SnO2 strong metal-support interaction (SMSI)), which can be continuously tuned by thermal treating the Pt-Sn/SiO2 precursor at different atmospheres and temperatures. The treatment in an oxidative atmosphere (O2) also can generate Pt-SnO2 SMSI, which became weak at higher temperatures and led to the growth of Pt nanoparticles (NPs). Pt-SnO2 SMSI became stronger when the oxygen atmosphere was changed to an inert (N2) atmosphere. Small metallic Pt NPs were formed and their dispersion was increased with increasing treatment temperature with inert gas. The catalyst presented a moderate activity in the dehydrogenation of lower alkanes. The treatment in a reductive atmosphere (H2) produced the strongest Pt-SnO2 SMSI and most active catalyst. Highly dispersed Sn surface-enriched Pt–Sn alloy NPs were formed on SiO2, in which Pt was most electron rich. The apparent activation energy in n-butane dehydrogenation is higher on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 than the corresponding one on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2. The kinetic studies revealed that the extreme isolation of Pt on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 (geometrical effects) dominantly contributed to its superior catalytic performance. The present work highlights the effects of thermal treatment-induced Pt-SnO2 SMSI, providing a new insight into the structure of Pt–Sn bimetallic catalysts and the promotional role of Sn in the dehydrogenation of lower alkanes to olefins on Pt surfaces. Keywords Strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) Propane/n-butane dehydrogenation Pt-Sn bimetallic catalyst Pt3Sn alloy Structure-sensitive reaction 1 Introduction Metal nanoparticles (NPs) dispersed on high-surface-area support materials constitute a large category of heterogeneous catalysts, widely applied in green chemistry, pollution abatement and clean energy production. The surface and/or metal-support interface of NPs provide active sites for the reactants to be adsorbed, activated and converted into new chemical species that are eventually released from the catalyst. Thus, elucidating the structure of metal-support interfaces, and their role during catalytic reactions are important for designing novel catalysts with optimal performance [1,2]. In 1978, the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) was first coined by Tauster et al. to explain the dramatic suppression of gas chemisorption (H2 and CO) on TiO2-supported VIII metals after high-temperature reduction in H2 [3,4]. Since then the SMSI have been extensively studied. The supporting material was expanded to many other transition-metal oxides (V2O3, NbO3, CeO2, etc.) which are easily reduced. It has now been generally established that the SMSI is related to the partial encapsulation of the catalytically active metal NPs by a thin layer of reduced oxide. Platinum (Pt) is a precious metal commonly used in heterogeneous catalysis. The occurrence of SMSI between Pt and the support usually requires that the supporting material is easily reduced, which limits the use of readily available SiO2 or Al2O3 supports for generating SMSI by the high-temperature H2 treatment. To obtain silica or alumina-supported Pt catalysts with SMSI, the generic method is to add the SMSI metal oxides (e.g. TiO2, SnO2) into the Pt/SiO2 (Al2O3) [5,6]. Among these catalysts, the Pt–Sn/SiO2 (Al2O3) catalyst has attracted enormous interest due to its enhanced catalytic behavior compared with Pt/support in CO oxidation [7,8], ethanol electro-oxidation (EOR) [9], dehydrogenation of lower alkanes [10,11] and other reactions [12–14]. The effect of the amount of Sn added on the catalytic properties has been extensively studied, and its promotional role was widely explained by the electronic and geometric modifications of Pt. However, discerning the natural structure of Pt–Sn/SiO2 (Al2O3) from the standpoint of SMSI have been rarely investigated even though this is a typical Pt-SnO2 SMSI system. Actually, the Pt-SnO2 SMSI in the Pt–Sn/SiO2 (Al2O3) catalyst systems are complicated and have various configurations such as Pt-SnO2 interface, core-shell, Pt-Sn metallic alloy, etc. Moreover, Pt-SnO2 SMSIs are also flexible, the thermal treatment or reaction conditions were bound to affect the Pt-SnO2 SMSI. For example, the active Pt-Sn metallic alloy phase (e.g. Pt3Sn and PtSn) easily collapse into each metal oxide under oxygen atmosphere, resulting in a decrease in the catalytic performances [15]. Similarly, during CO oxidation, Pt3Sn segregates into SnOx and an Sn deficient metal phase due to the stability of the metal oxide and the strong bonding of CO to Pt. Thermal treatment is generally applied during catalyst preparation and is crucial for the manipulation of SMSI in Pt–Sn/SiO2 (Al2O3) catalyst systems [16], but it has not been carefully reexamined and has not been paid enough attention. In this study, we report the construction of Pt-SnO2 SMSIs with different configurations by the direct thermal treatment of the Pt–Sn/SiO2 precursor. The effects of the thermal atmosphere and temperature on the regulation of the Pt-SnO2 SMSI in the Pt–Sn/SiO2 catalyst were systemically investigated. Bulk and surface characterization techniques including X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS), CO diffuse reflectance infrared fourier transform spectroscopy (CO-DRIFTS) were combined to elucidate the nature of the Pt-SnO2 SMSI. After being applied in the dehydrogenation of lower alkanes (propane and n-butane), the relationship between the Pt-SnO2 SMSI and catalytic properties, as well as the reaction mechanism were further discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Silica (JRC-SIO-9) was thermally treated at 773 K in air for 3 h and subsequently used as the support (after calcination, 334 m2 g−1). The Pt/SiO2 precursor was prepared by impregnating the SiO2 support with an adequate volume of aqueous H2PtCl6·6H2O (3 wt% Pt), with stirring at 353 K for 3 h, and then drying at 353 K for 20 h. The precipitate was denoted as the Pt/SiO2 precursor. A bimetallic Pt–Sn/SiO2 precursor was prepared by sequential impregnation. The Pt/SiO2 precursor was added to an acetone solution of SnCl2·2H2O (97%, Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Ltd., Tokyo, Japan), stirred at 353 K for 3 h, and dried at 353 K for 20 h. The Pt content was 3 wt%. The molar ratio of Pt to Sn was 1. The catalyst precursors were loaded in a quartz reactor and treated in situ with one of three different atmospheres (total flow rate, 50 mL min−1) at 773 K or 1073 K for 1 h: (i) oxidative atmosphere, consisting of 20 vol% O2 in N2; (ii) inert atmosphere, consisting of N2 ; or (iii) reductive atmosphere, consisting of 20 vol% H2 in N2. The obtained catalysts were denoted as Pt–Sn/SiO2_xK O2/N2/H2, where x indicates the treatment temperature. After treatment, the catalyst was purged with N2 (100 mL min−1) and the temperature was adjusted to the reaction temperature. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface areas were estimated from N2 isotherms obtained using a BELSORP 28SA instrument (BEL Japan, Osaka, Japan) at 77 K. After the treatment, the samples were evacuated at 573 K for 3 h prior to measurements. TEM images were obtained using a JEOL JEM–2100F instrument (JEOL, Ltd., Tokyo, Japan). The samples were prepared by depositing drops of a methanol suspension containing small amounts of the powders onto carbon-coated copper grids (Okenshoji Co. Ltd., Tokyo, Japan), followed by evaporating the methanol in air. The XRD patterns were obtained using a MultiFlex DR powder X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku, Tokyo, Japan) with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5405 Å). The samples were scanned from 2θ = 38° to 46° with a scanning resolution of 0.01°. X-ray absorption experiments were carried out using beamline BL01B1 at SPring-8 (The third-generation synchrotron radiation facility, Hyogo, Japan). The ring energy was 8 GeV, and the stored current was 99.5 mA. The Pt L3 and L2-edge (11.56 and 13.27 keV, respectively) X-ray absorption spectra were recorded in air at room temperature using a Si (1 1 1) monochromator in the transmission mode. The Sn K-edge (29.19 keV) X-ray absorption spectra were recorded in air at room temperature using a Si (3 1 1) monochromator in the fluorescence mode. Data processing was performed using REX2000 Ver.2.5.9 (Rigaku) and FEFF8.40 programs. The amount of CO adsorbed on the catalyst at room temperature was measured by the CO pulse method using an Okura BP-2 instrument (Okura Riken, Japan) interfaced with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Prior to CO adsorption, the catalyst precursor was treated in situ with an oxidative/inert/reductive atmosphere at 773 K or 1073 K for 1 h. DRIFTS experiments were performed on a FT/IR-600 JASCO spectrometer (Jasco Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan) equipped with a mercury–cadmium–telluride (MCT) detector to investigate the structure of Pt and Pt–Sn NPs using CO as a probe molecule. All spectra were collected with 128 scans at a resolution of 4 cm−1. The samples (20 mg) were placed in an in-situ DRIFTS cell with ZnSe windows, pretreated with 5% H2/Ar (50 mL min−1) or O2/N2 (50 mL min−1) at 573 K for 1 h, and then cooled to 323 K under N2 flow. After cooling to 323 K, the backgrounds were collected. CO adsorption was performed by flowing 10% CO/He at 323 K. 2.3 Dehydrogenation reactions and kinetic studies The catalyst precursor (50 mg, 25–50 mesh) was placed between quartz wool in a quartz reactor (i.d. 10 mm). After treatment, propane dehydrogenation was carried out at atmospheric pressure using 20 vol% propane in N2 at 773 K. The total flow rate was 100 mL min−1 and the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was about 22,000 h−1. The gas composition was analyzed using an on-line Shimadzu GC-8A gas chromatograph (Shimadzu Corp., Kyoto, Japan) equipped with TCD (5Amolecular sieve column) and flame ionization detector (FID; Porapak-Q column). For n-butane dehydrogenation, a feed of 20 vol% n-butane in N2 was used at 823 K, with a total flow rate of 100 mL min−1. The gas composition was analyzed using an on-line Shimadzu GC-8A gas chromatograph (Shimadzu Corp., Kyoto, Japan) equipped with a TCD (5A molecular sieve column) and FID (Rt-Alumina BOND MAPD column). The initial turnover frequency (TOF) for the dehydrogenation of n-butane was calculated by two methods as follows: (1) TOF = n C 3 H 8 / n - C 4 H 10 × c o n v . × s e l . ÷ n exposed P t S - 1 (2) TOF = n C 3 H 8 \; / n - C 4 H 10 × c o n v . × s e l . ÷ n loading P t S - 1 where conv. is the initial conversion of C3H8 or n-C4H10, sel. is the initial selectivity towards C3H6 in the dehydrogenation of C3H8 or C4 alkene products including 1-C4H8, trans-2-C4H8, cis-2-C4H8 and 1,3-C4H6 in the dehydrogenation of n-C4H10. The mole of exposed Pt on the surface was estimated by the CO chemisorption. The loading of Pt was 153.8 mol·g−1. The kinetic experiments in n-butane dehydrogenation were conducted at temperatures ranging from 733 to 813 K under atmospheric pressure. The total feed flow rate was kept 100 mL/min for all the runs. In each experiment, the catalyst precursor (25 mg) was loaded into the reactor and thermally treated in situ in a flow of H2 or N2 at 1073 K for 1 h before the reaction. One thermocouple was placed at the side of the catalyst bed to control the temperature of the furnace. In addition, a second thermocouple was placed in contact with the top of the catalyst bed during the reaction. 3 Results 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 Analysis of the geometric effect in Pt-SnO2 SMSI The bright field TEM images displayed in Fig. 1 show the distribution of NPs on the silica support. The mean particle sizes of the Pt/SiO2 and Pt–Sn/SiO2 catalysts are summarized in Table 1 . The data shows that the oxidative atmosphere led to poor Pt dispersion on Pt/SiO2 catalysts. Large NPs (∼26 nm) were observed, whose particle size was little or no affected by the treatment temperature. However, the addition of Sn clearly affected the Pt dispersion on Pt–Sn/SiO2 catalysts even in the oxidative atmosphere. The average Pt particle size was approximately 3.3 nm in Pt–Sn/SiO2_773 K O2, 8.7 nm in Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K O2, smaller than 8.7 nm in Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K O2 and 25.6 nm in Pt/SiO2_773 K O2. Treating Pt–Sn/SiO2 catalysts at a lower temperature in an oxidative atmosphere favors Pt dispersion. Inert treatment atmosphere enhanced the Pt dispersion. The average size of the Pt NPs was about 9 nm on Pt/SiO2_773 K N2, and 11 nm on Pt/SiO2_1073 K N2, much smaller than Pt/SiO2 catalysts treated in an oxidative atmosphere. This situation became more obvious in the reductive atmosphere, which produced the smallest Pt NPs (∼2 nm) even after reduction at high temperature (1073 K). Pt dispersion in Pt–Sn/SiO2 catalysts was also enhanced by the addition of Sn in the inert treatment. The average size of Pt NPs in Pt/SiO2_1073 K N2, Pt–Sn/SiO2_773 K N2 and Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 was estimated to be 10.9, 3.1 and 2.2 nm, respectively. It is also worth noting that the size of the NPs decreased at higher temperatures, which is opposite to the case under the oxidative treatment. The treatment at higher temperature in a N2 atmosphere produced smaller NPs. Under the reductive atmosphere, the addition of Sn into Pt/SiO2 did not significantly influence the size of NPs like O2, N2-treated catalysts. H2-treated bimetallic catalysts at different temperatures exhibited a small particle size, similar to Pt/SiO2 monometallic catalysts. The XRD patterns of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . Metallic Pt with a face centered cubic (fcc) structure (ICSD41525) was observed in the Pt/SiO2_O2, Pt/SiO2_N2, Pt/SiO2_H2 and Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K O2. Based on the full width at half-maximum (FWHM) of the characteristic peak of Pt (1 1 1) at 2θ = 39.8°, the crystallite sizes of metallic Pt were estimated and the results were consistent with the mean particle size estimated from TEM images (Table 1). In the XRD patterns of the Pt–Sn catalysts treated under a reductive atmosphere (Fig. 2(C)), a clear peak was present at 2θ = 39° for Pt3Sn phase (1 1 1) (ICSD 105796) and two peaks appeared at 2θ = 42° and 44° for a PtSn phase (ICSD 42593), indicating the Pt–Sn alloying on SiO2. The XRD fitting results (Table 2 ) revealed that 80% (molar) of Pt was present as Pt3Sn, and 20% of Pt as PtSn. The molar ratio of Pt3Sn to PtSn is 0.57: 0.43. In fact, various Pt–Sn alloys (substitutional solid-solution alloys) including Pt0.94Sn0.06, Pt0.93Sn0.07, Pt0.9Sn0.1and Pt0.75Sn0.25 (Pt3Sn) with a crystal structure identical to that of the Pt metal (fcc) have been reported [17]. Their XRD patterns indicated a linear relationship between the Sn composition in these Pt–Sn alloys and the peak shift of the Pt (1 1 1) diffraction line compared with the Pt metal (Vegard’s law) (Fig. S1). The lattice parameter of Pt–Sn alloys became larger than that of metallic Pt (Table S1). In the present study, the presence of Pt3Sn with an fcc and PtSn with a hexagonal structure in Pt–Sn/SiO2_H2 catalysts suggests the favorable formation of these two stable Pt-Sn alloys under the reductive conditions when the nominal Pt:Sn ratio was 1. Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcat.2018.06.028. The XRD patterns of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . Metallic Pt with a face centered cubic (fcc) structure (ICSD41525) was observed in the Pt/SiO2_O2, Pt/SiO2_N2, Pt/SiO2_H2 and Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K O2. Based on the full width at half-maximum (FWHM) of the characteristic peak of Pt (1 1 1) at 2θ = 39.8°, the crystallite sizes of metallic Pt were estimated and the results were consistent with the mean particle size estimated from TEM images (Table 1). In the XRD patterns of the Pt–Sn catalysts treated under a reductive atmosphere (Fig. 2(C)), a clear peak was present at 2θ = 39° for Pt3Sn phase (1 1 1) (ICSD 105796) and two peaks appeared at 2θ = 42° and 44° for a PtSn phase (ICSD 42593), indicating the Pt–Sn alloying on SiO2. The XRD fitting results (Table 2 ) revealed that 80% (molar) of Pt was present as Pt3Sn, and 20% of Pt as PtSn. The molar ratio of Pt3Sn to PtSn is 0.57: 0.43. In fact, various Pt–Sn alloys (substitutional solid-solution alloys) including Pt0.94Sn0.06, Pt0.93Sn0.07, Pt0.9Sn0.1and Pt0.75Sn0.25 (Pt3Sn) with a crystal structure identical to that of the Pt metal (fcc) have been reported [17]. Their XRD patterns indicated a linear relationship between the Sn composition in these Pt–Sn alloys and the peak shift of the Pt (1 1 1) diffraction line compared with the Pt metal (Vegard’s law) (Fig. S1 ). The lattice parameter of Pt–Sn alloys became larger than that of metallic Pt (Table S1). In the present study, the presence of Pt3Sn with an fcc and PtSn with a hexagonal structure in Pt–Sn/SiO2_H2 catalysts suggests the favorable formation of these two stable Pt-Sn alloys under the reductive conditions when the nominal Pt:Sn ratio was 1. No XRD pattern for metallic Pt or any other crystalline species was found on Pt–Sn/SiO2_773 K O2, Pt–Sn/SiO2_773 K N2 and Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2, and no diffraction lines due to Sn compounds such as Sn metal, SnO and SnO2 appeared in all Pt–Sn/SiO2 catalysts. Therefore, XAFS was used to study the states of these catalysts. Different from XRD analysis that requires large well-ordered crystallites of the catalyst tested, XAFS can detect target elements in both crystals and amorphous/microcrystalline structures that are common in supported catalysts, addressing some limitations of XRD measurements. The k 3-weighted EXAFS oscillations and their Fourier transforms (FTs) at the Pt L3-edge for Pt–Sn/SiO2 catalysts presented in Fig. S2 show Pt–Pt linkage on the Pt–Sn/SiO2_773 K O2 and Pt–Sn/SiO2_N2. This indicated that the Pt species (PtCl6 2−) was reduced to the metallic state even after treatment under the oxidized or inert atmosphere. The k 3-weighted EXAFS oscillation of Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 was weak and much different from that of Pt foil. A weak and split feature appeared around 0.21–0.28 nm in its FT spectrum. This feature suggested the interference of scattered electrons of Sn and Pt atoms from Pt–Sn alloys. No XRD pattern for metallic Pt or any other crystalline species was found on Pt–Sn/SiO2_773 K O2, Pt–Sn/SiO2_773 K N2 and Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2, and no diffraction lines due to Sn compounds such as Sn metal, SnO and SnO2 appeared in all Pt–Sn/SiO2 catalysts. Therefore, XAFS was used to study the states of these catalysts. Different from XRD analysis that requires large well-ordered crystallites of the catalyst tested, XAFS can detect target elements in both crystals and amorphous/microcrystalline structures that are common in supported catalysts, addressing some limitations of XRD measurements. The k 3-weighted EXAFS oscillations and their Fourier transforms (FTs) at the Pt L3-edge for Pt–Sn/SiO2 catalysts presented in Fig. S2 show Pt–Pt linkage on the Pt–Sn/SiO2_773 K O2 and Pt–Sn/SiO2_N2. This indicated that the Pt species (PtCl6 2−) was reduced to the metallic state even after treatment under the oxidized or inert atmosphere. The k 3-weighted EXAFS oscillation of Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 was weak and much different from that of Pt foil. A weak and split feature appeared around 0.21–0.28 nm in its FT spectrum. This feature suggested the interference of scattered electrons of Sn and Pt atoms from Pt–Sn alloys. The Sn K-edge XANES spectra of the Pt–Sn/SiO2 catalysts and the reference samples (Sn foil and SnO2) are shown in Fig. 3 (A). The spectra revealed that SnCl2·2H2O in the catalyst precursor was transformed into SnO2 after oxidative/inert treatments, generating white line intensities similar to those of SnO2. Fig. S2 shows Sn K-edge XANES spectra of Pt–Sn/SiO2 catalyst precursor, Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 and reference samples (SnCl2·2H2O, Sn foil, Sn(II)O and Sn(IV)O2). The white lines of Pt–Sn/SiO2 precursor and Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 were similar with each other, which were totally different from that of starting material (SnCl2·2H2O) and presents the characteristic property of SnO2. The white line intensities are much higher than that of SnO, and slightly lower than that of SnO2 (Fig. S2 (B)). The peak assignable to Sn–O linkage around 0.16 nm was also observed on both catalysts. It suggests that Sn2+ was oxidized to Sn4+ during the impregnation in air, and the following thermal treatment in N2 atmosphere did not drastically change the state of Sn. Based on these results, we proposed that highly dispersed SnO2 was formed on Pt–Sn/SiO2 precursor and Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2. The white line position of Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 was higher than that of Sn foil, but lower than that of SnO2, suggesting the partial reduction of SnO2 in Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2. Accordingly, besides Sn–O bonding in the FT of the EXAFS oscillations of Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2, a peak at around 0.27 nm suggested the contribution of Sn–Pt linkages due to the formation of a Pt–Sn alloy phase. In addition, a weak peak of Sn–Pt linkages in the FT of the EXAFS oscillations of Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 also suggests the proximity of Pt and SnO2 on the catalyst. The Sn K-edge XANES spectra of the Pt–Sn/SiO2 catalysts and the reference samples (Sn foil and SnO2) are shown in Fig. 3 (A). The spectra revealed that SnCl2·2H2O in the catalyst precursor was transformed into SnO2 after oxidative/inert treatments, generating white line intensities similar to those of SnO2. Fig. S2 shows Sn K-edge XANES spectra of Pt–Sn/SiO2 catalyst precursor, Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 and reference samples (SnCl2·2H2O, Sn foil, Sn(II)O and Sn(IV)O2). The white lines of Pt–Sn/SiO2 precursor and Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 were similar with each other, which were totally different from that of starting material (SnCl2·2H2O) and presents the characteristic property of SnO2. The white line intensities are much higher than that of SnO, and slightly lower than that of SnO2 (Fig. S2(B)). The peak assignable to Sn–O linkage around 0.16 nm was also observed on both catalysts. It suggests that Sn2+ was oxidized to Sn4+ during the impregnation in air, and the following thermal treatment in N2 atmosphere did not drastically change the state of Sn. Based on these results, we proposed that highly dispersed SnO2 was formed on Pt–Sn/SiO2 precursor and Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2. Accordingly, besides Sn–O bonding in the FT of the EXAFS oscillations of Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2, a peak at around 0.27 nm suggested the contribution of Sn–Pt linkages due to the formation of a Pt–Sn alloy phase. In addition, a weak peak of Sn–Pt linkages in the FT of the EXAFS oscillations of Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 also suggests the proximity of Pt and SnO2 on the catalyst. For monometallic Pt catalysts, the fraction of exposed metal atoms, or dispersion, can be determined by CO chemisorption. The result for the small NPs (<1 nm) was not counted by TEM, while CO chemisorption includes all Pt NPs. Table 1 summarizes the amount of CO adsorbed on the catalysts, which reveal that CO adsorption decreased with increasing Pt dispersion on Pt/SiO2 catalysts. About 54.9 mol g−1of CO adsorbed on Pt/SiO2_773 K H2, while 3.8 mol g−1of CO adsorbed on the Pt/SiO2_773 K N2. However, CO chemisorption is not an accurate method to determine Pt dispersion on Pt-Sn binary catalysts, as it is influenced not only by Pt dispersion, but also by the catalyst surface properties. For example, the size of Pt-containing NPs on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 was ca. 2.2 nm, which is similar to Pt/SiO2_773 K H2 (2.0 nm). However, the amount of CO adsorbed on the former one was much lower (10.6 vs. 54.9 mol g−1). This drop in CO chemisorption suggests the surface modification of Pt NPs by SnO2 like the traditional Pt–SnO2 SMSI phenomenon. Similarly, the amount of CO adsorbed on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 was also much lower than that on Pt/SiO2_773 K H2 (6.5 vs. 54.9 mol g−1). Sn species (Sn metal or partially reduced SnO2) were probably located on the surfaces of the Pt-Sn alloy NPs and blocked Pt sites from the uptake of CO. Based on the TEM, XRD, XAFS and CO adsorption results, the proposed structures of Pt–Sn/SiO2 catalysts treated under various atmospheres are depicted in Scheme 1 . Oxidative treatment of the Pt–Sn/SiO2 precursor induced the formation of Pt metal particles and SnO2. The particle size of Pt increased with increasing treatment temperature. With inert atmosphere treatment, small Pt NPs and SnO2 were generated. The Pt–Sn alloy NPs were formed after treatment under a reductive atmosphere. Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 featured small Pt3Sn and PtSn alloy particles (∼2.6 nm) decorated with Sn species. 3.1.2 Analysis of the electronic effect in Pt-SnO2 SMSI XPS measurements were performed over the catalysts and Pt/SiO2_773 K H2 as the reference sample (Fig. S3). No clear energy shift was present over Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2, Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 and Pt/SiO2_773 K H2. Therefore, XANES spectra were analyzed to probe the electronic structure of Pt in these catalysts. The Pt L3-XANES spectra of the Pt–Sn/SiO2 catalysts and reference samples (Pt/SiO2_773 K H2 and Pt foil) are shown in Fig. 4 (A). As the magnitude of the white line provides an index of the d-band vacancies of Pt (Fig. S4), the higher white line intensity in Pt NPs in Pt/SiO2_773 K H2 than that in Pt foil indicated that Pt NPs were slightly more electron deficient than that in Pt foil. Combining the Pt L2-XANES spectra (Fig. S5), the number of unfilled d states (h Ts) was calculated (see Supporting information) and the results are shown in Fig. 4(B). Pt/SiO2_773 K H2 had a higher number of unfilled d-states (h Ts = 1.79) than Pt foil (h Ts = 1.60). Moreover, the Pt particle size on the Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K O2 catalyst was approximately 8.7 nm and its d-band vacancy of Pt atoms was 1.72, which was higher than that of the Pt foil, and lower than that of Pt/SiO2 _773 K O2. This result might be attributed to size effects of the Pt NPs. More dispersed Pt NPs with smaller size show greater electron deficiency. As the magnitude of the white line provides an index of the d-band vacancies of Pt (Fig. S4), the higher white line intensity in Pt NPs in Pt/SiO2_773 K H2 than that in Pt foil indicated that Pt NPs were slightly more electron deficient than that in Pt foil. Combining the Pt L2-XANES spectra (Fig. S5), the number of unfilled d states (h Ts) was calculated (see Supporting information) and the results are shown in Fig. 4(B). Pt/SiO2_773 K H2 had a higher number of unfilled d-states (h Ts = 1.79) than Pt foil (h Ts = 1.60). Moreover, the Pt particle size on the Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K O2 catalyst was approximately 8.7 nm and its d-band vacancy of Pt atoms was 1.72, which was higher than that of the Pt foil, and lower than that of Pt/SiO2 _773 K O2. This result might be attributed to size effects of the Pt NPs. More dispersed Pt NPs with smaller size show greater electron deficiency. The number of unfilled d states varied in the order: Pt/SiO2_773 K H2 > Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 > Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2. The similarity of the particle sizes in these catalysts enabled us to eliminate particle size as a factor that influence the observed unfilled d states. A lower Pt d-band vacancy (higher electron density) of Pt on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 than that on Pt/SiO2_773 K H2 indicated the interaction between Pt and SnO2. The Pt–SnO x (x < 2) nanostructure was probably present at the interface of Pt and SnO2. Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 gave the lowest white line intensity (highest electron density), suggesting that Pt atoms in Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 were the most electron-rich among the catalysts. It seems that Pt–Sn alloying under the reductive treatment had a stronger impact on the electronic state of Pt than traditional Pt–SnO x SMSI. Also, more electron donation from Sn to Pt occurred in the Pt-Sn alloy. A series of DRIFTS measurements were performed using CO as the probe molecule to further study the properties of the catalysts (Fig. 5 ). When Pt/SiO2_773 K H2 was exposed to 10% CO in He gas, a band appeared at around 2086 cm−1 with a small shoulder located at ∼2078 cm−1at 303 K, which according to the model of CO bonding to Pt [18] was assignable to linearly adsorbed CO on Pt terrace sites and low coordination-like steps, edges, and corners of Pt sites, respectively. A lower number of PtPt bonds for each Pt surface atom leads to a higher electron density available for back-donation to the 2π * orbitals of CO, which decreases the νCO frequency. Moreover, these bands were weakened by purging with N2, but still remained after treatment at 373 K, indicating strong bonding between the Pt sites and adsorbed CO. It should also be noted that no bridge-bonded CO was observed around1850 cm−1 on Pt/SiO2_773 K H2 due to the highly dispersion of Pt. As suggested by the XRD results, Pt–Sn alloys were formed on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2. DRIFT spectra shown in Fig. 5(B) presents clear spectral differences from those of Pt/SiO2: (i) after CO adsorption, the intensity of νCO related to the linearly adsorbed CO on Pt–Sn/SiO2 was lower than that on Pt/SiO2; (ii) unlike the Pt/SiO2 sample, Pt–Sn/SiO2 featured a narrower band without shoulders or tails, which may be considered a single peak, suggesting that more homogeneous Pt sites were present in Pt–Sn/SiO2. Sn covering the step, edge, and corner sites of the Pt NPs probably occurred; (iii) at full coverage the position of the band on Pt–Sn/SiO2 was located in a lower energy range than that of the Pt/SiO2 catalysts (2073–2075 cm−1 vs. 2086–2076 cm−1), which suggested an electronic modification of Pt by alloying with Sn. Also, electron donation from Sn to Pt lowered the CO vibration frequency due to a higher electron density available for back-donation to the 2π * orbitals of C in the CO bonding to Pt; (iv) throughout the desorption experiments for Pt–Sn/SiO2, the peak retained its symmetrical shape. Additionally, it was almost completely desorbed from Pt–Sn/SiO2 at 373 K, whereas this peak remained on the Pt/SiO2 catalyst. The DRIFT spectra of Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 were much different from those of Pt/SiO2_773 K H2 and Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2. A gas-phase CO band (νCO = 2172, 2118 cm−1), a linear Pt–CO adsorption vibration (νCO = 2087 cm−1) and gaseous CO2 rotation–vibration P and R bands at 2360 and 2339 cm−1 respectively, are shown in Fig. 5(C). With CO adsorption, a major νCO peak was observed at 2172 cm−1. After purging with N2 for 2 min, the intensity of this band greatly decreased. The band at νCO = 2118 cm−1 also decreased in intensity and split into two peaks at 2116 and 2078 cm−1. Purging with N2 for 5 min led to the disappearance of the band and a low intensity band remained at 2078 cm−1, which could be ascribed to the typical linear Pt–CO adsorption vibration frequency. This result indicated that the surface of Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 contained a small amount of accessible Pt0. As previously reported, the adsorption and desorption of CO2 strongly depends on the support material. Often, no CO species can be detected on the surface of SiO2-supported catalysts [19]. However, tin oxide coexisted with metallic Pt on SiO2 in the present study, and constituted an oxygen reservoir that could react with CO adsorbed to neighboring platinum sites [20]. As a result, monodentate carbonate adsorption bands related to the OCO vibrational modes appeared at 1558 cm−1, while the gaseous CO2 adsorption band appeared at 2360 and 2339 cm−1. The intensities of these IR bands did not significantly change after purging with N2 for 5 min, demonstrating the strong bonding of CO with O atoms from tin oxide. The DRIFT spectra of Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K O2 were similar to those of Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 with a much stronger signal for gaseous CO2. This was attributed to the presence of SnO2 with a higher oxidative ability or larger particle size than that on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073K N2. To determine the contribution of SnO2 to the CO-DRIFT spectra, SnO2/SiO2 catalysts were prepared using the impregnation–calcination (air, 773 K, 3 h) process, and then pretreated in situ in IR cells with H2 or O2 at 573 K for 1 h for CO-DRIFT spectra measurements (Fig. S6). Both gas-phase CO bands (νCO = ∼2172, 2118 cm−1) and gaseous CO2 rotation–vibration P and R bands (νCO = ∼2360 and 2339 cm−1) were observed on SnO2/SiO2_573 K O2 and SnO2/SiO2_573 K H2. These signals on SnO2/SiO2_573 K O2 were much stronger and stable than those on SnO2/SiO2_573 K H2, confirming the contribution of SnO2 on the catalyst surface to gaseous CO and CO2 signals in the CO-DRIFT spectra. It is worth noting that there are no CO2-DRIFTS signals on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2. This lack of signals indicated that SnO or Sn decorated the Pt3Sn alloys, but not SnO2. The model shown in Fig. 5(B) is closer to the real catalyst during the dehydrogenation reactions. The XAFS and XPS analysis showing SnO2 can be attributed to the exposure of the catalysts to air, which will be studied in future. The XAFS and XPS analysis showing SnO2 can be attributed to the exposure of the catalysts to air, which will be studied in future. 3.2 Dehydrogenation performances of Pt–Sn/SiO2 catalysts Light alkenes (ethene, propene and butenes) are used as building blocks for producing rubber, plastics and other polymers. They are often produced by steam cracking of alkanes/naphtha or recovered from fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) of heavy oil [21–23]. However, these processes generally exhibit low alkene selectivity and consume large amounts of energy. As the demand of light alkene gradually increases, the catalytic dehydrogenation of C2–C4 alkanes becomes an attractive alternative method for light olefin production, particularly, gas price has recently dropped to about 75% of the price in 2005 due to the increased supply of natural gas containing rich C2–C4 alkanes [24,25]. Employed in the dehydrogenation of propane, the catalysts treated under the oxidative atmosphere showed no activity except for some low activity with Pt–Sn/SiO2_773 K O2 (Fig. 6 ). With the inert atmosphere, the Pt/SiO2 catalysts were inactive, while the Pt–Sn bimetallic catalysts showed activity, which increased with increasing treatment temperature (1073 K vs. 773 K). Under a reductive atmosphere, the propane conversion was only 5% on Pt/SiO2_773 K H2. However, it improved to 21.3% on Pt/SiO2_1073 K H2. This improvement was attributed to the electronic modification of Pt NPs by the Pt-SiO2 SMSI which results from the H2 reduction at high temperature, as shown in our previous work [26]. With the reduced Pt–Sn bimetallic systems, propane conversion was 22.5% on Pt–Sn/SiO2_773 K H2 and 26.5% on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2. The selectivity for propylene over Pt/SiO2_773 K H2 and Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 was 94.9 and 99.5%, respectively (Table 3 ). Trace amounts of methane and ethane were detected as byproducts when Pt/SiO2_773 K H2 was used as the catalyst. And the catalytic activity gradually decreased with the reaction time. In contrast, Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 exhibited much better stability during 3 h of reaction time (Fig. 7 ). In the dehydrogenation of n-butane, similar results were observed on O2, N2 and H2-treated catalysts. Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 gave the highest n-butane conversions, and afforded a relatively high yield of 1,3-butadiene–the important product among the products from the dehydrogenation of n-butane. Two main types of catalysts are typically used for the nonoxidative dehydrogenation of light olefins, namely the Pt-based [27] and metal oxide-based catalysts such as CrOx [28] and VOx [29–30]. A quantitative comparison of the catalytic performances, shown in Fig. S7 and Table 3, illustrates that Pt-based catalysts showed greater activity and selectivity than other metal oxide catalysts under relatively commercially attractive conditions (high space velocities, lower reaction temperature). Furthermore, considering that Pt-based catalysts typically have lower loadings than metal oxides catalysts (with 5–20 wt%), it is evident that Pt represents the most active element in the dehydrogenation of lower alkanes. The TOF values based on the loading amount of Pt (3 wt%, 153.8 mol·g−1) and TOF values based on the surface exposed Pt measured with CO adsorption were calculated. Although these values are a very rough approximation of the real TOF of the catalyst, Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 exhibited a significantly higher TOF value and better performance than other Pt-based catalysts. In the case of propane dehydrogenation, the TOF values on Pt/SiO2_773 K H2, Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 and Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 are 0.3, 4.6 and 11.1 s−1, respectively. Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 gave the highest TOF, almost 40-fold higher than that on Pt/SiO2_773 K H2. The order of TOF values on the catalysts in the dehydrogenation of n-butane exhibited a similar tendency. Moreover, Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 showed ≧99% selectivity for propylene or butenes, exhibiting much superior behavior than the metal oxide catalysts. In order to ensure that the kinetic experiments were conducted under kinetic control, the experimental conditions in the present work were calculated with GradientCheck (https://engineering.purdue.edu/~catalyst/gradientcheck/index.html) to determine the effects of mass and heat transports on the reaction. The results shown in Tables S2, S3 and Fig. S8 demonstrated that the influences of the external mass were eliminated. The temperature gap between the catalyst surface and the gas region was in the range of 0.8 K to 1.2 K for the highest active catalyst, or 0.3 K for the moderately active catalyst. The arrhenius plots for the formation rates of 1,3-C4H6 and the alkenes on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 and Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 are shown in Fig. 8 . The relative kinetic values are shown in Table 4 . These data revealed that the apparent activation energy was larger on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 (123.2 kJ mol−1 calculated from the 1,3-C4H6 formation rate, 33.0 kJ mol−1 calculated from the alkene formation rate) than Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 (76.8 or 4.4 kJ mol−1). The frequency factor A increased by a factor of 103 for Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 (A ≈ 5.0 × 109, calculated from the 1,3-C4H6 formation rate, and 7.4 × 104, calculated from the alkene formation rate) compared with that of Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 (A ≈ 2.5 × 106 or 2.3 × 102). The effect of C4H10 feed gas partial pressure on the formation rate of 1,3-C4H6 and all C4 alkenes (1-C4H8, trans-2-C4H8, cis-2-C4H8 and 1,3-C4H6) on Pt–Sn/SiO2 catalysts subjected to inert and reductive atmospheres is shown in Fig. S9. With increasing n-butane partial pressure, the 1,3-C4H6 formation rate slightly increased, while all C4 alkenes clearly increased on both catalysts. A lower C4H10 partial pressure is favorable for increasing the selectivity for 1,3-C4H6. The dehydrogenation of n-butane is thermodynamically limited and highly endothermic. A lower C4H10 partial pressure is favorable for increasing the selectivity for 1,3-C4H6. 4 Discussion 4.1 The flexibility of Pt-SnO2 SMSI The strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) in various catalyst systems have received considerable attention ever since its original discovery by Tauster et al. in 1978. Its formation generally requires high-temperature reduction in H2 to activate the surface of reducible metal oxide support [31]. In 2015, Zhang et al. reported another example of SMSI between Au NPs and hydroxyapatite (HAP) through high-temperature oxidation in O2, the opposite condition for the classical SMSI [32]. The encapsulation of Au NPs by the HAP support, electron transfer, and changes in CO adsorption are identical to the classical SMSI. Coincidentally, the present work investigated the construction and regulation of SMSI through oxidative or inert treatment in a Pt–Sn/SiO2 catalyst system. Pt-SnO2 SMSI was found even on Pt–Sn/SiO2_773 K O2 and enhanced the dispersion of Pt NPs. Higher oxidation temperature weakened the Pt-SnO2 SMSI, leading to the aggregation of Pt NPs. The inert atmosphere also induced Pt-SnO2 SMSI, the size of the Pt NPs was ca. 2.2 nm on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2, but they were as large as10.9 nm in the absence of Sn. Both Pt–Sn/SiO2_773 K O2 and Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 showed catalytic activity in the dehydrogenation of lower alkanes. These results suggested the emergence of classic SMSI between Pt and SnO2 after oxidative or inert treatment, which might be attributed to the work function and surface energy of Pt and Sn. The classic SMSI is generally explained by the physical covering/encapsulation of metal NPs with metal oxides, thus revealing its geometrical nature (Scheme 2 ) [33,34]. The characterization results presented here the classic surface modification of Pt NPs (partial coverage or encapsulation) on all supported Pt–Sn catalysts regardless of the treatment atmosphere and temperature. Pt atoms of low coordination such as steps, edges and corners were covered by Sn species (SnO2, SnOx or Sn), detected by CO adsorption and CO-DRIFT analysis. This surface modification geometrically diluted the Pt NPs, and the evolution of the Pt dispersion was clearly present with various configurations of Pt-SnO2 SMSI (Scheme 2). The Pt-SnO2 SMSI in Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 isolated the Pt NPs into smaller ones. H2 treatment at high temperatures induced the strongest SMSI. Sn surface-enriched Pt-Sn alloy formed on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2, in which the Pt atoms were extremely isolated and surrounded by Sn atoms. In the heterogeneous catalysis, depositing the metal on a support with high surface area is the easiest and most practical way to produce metals with small particle size. The results presented here implied that the regulation of SMSI between the metal and the SMSI metal oxide (promoter) on SiO2 is another efficient way to generate small metallic NPs, being advantageous for reducing the usage of noble metals in industrial applications. An approximate calculation, also confirmed by plenty of experimental data, ascertained that the properties of a metal start to change near a diameter of about 2 nm [35]. In order to study an intrinsic size effect on the metal, much care has been taken as much as possible to choose a neutral nonactive support (e.g. SiO2) to avoid any possible metal-support interaction. It has been generally observed that group VIII noble metals supported on SiO2 exhibit higher binding energies of the core levels than the corresponding bulk metals, indicating decreased electron density at anatomic site. With the help of the powerful tool of XAFS, the present work found that the small Pt NPs on Pt/SiO2_773 K H2 presented the largest d vacancy among bulk Pt foil and the catalysts with larger Pt NPs (e.g. Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K O2). The increase of Pt dispersion here is accompanied with the increase in d vacancy of Pt atoms. However, the presence of SMSI complicates the situation and raises one important question. What causes the electronic states of Pt to change? the increased geometric dispersion due to SMSI? or the change transfer between the metal and SMSI metal oxides? A previous XPS analysis of Pt/SiO2 (non-SMSI state) and Pt/TiO2 (SMSI state) suggested that an electron transfer occurs from the reduced Ti centers to the Pt particles [36]. XANES spectra in this study indicated that unfilled d states of Pt varied in the order Pt/SiO2_773 K H2 > Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 > Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2. Considering the similarity in particle size between these three catalysts, smaller d vacancies on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 and Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 could be solely due to electron transfer to platinum with the addition of Sn. Sn sites make contact with the Pt particle on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 and donate their electrons. On Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2, Pt-Sn alloying with the hybridization of Pt d- and Sn p-electrons led to increased electron density at Pt atoms, which is consistent with the previous reports [37,38]. 4.2 Effect of SMSI on dehydrogenation of lower alkanes Supported Pt NPs are among the most suitable catalysts for the thermal dehydrogenation of lower alkanes due to its high density of electronic states close to the Fermi level, a characteristic that contributes to CH bond activation. In the present work, Pt atoms in the Pt–SnO x (x < 2) interface (Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2) and Pt3Sn alloy (Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2) become more electron rich than those without Sn. The related theoretical calculations have indicated that electron rich Pt atoms can lower the energy barrier for propylene desorption from the catalyst surface, inhibiting propylene deep dehydrogenation and ensuring the high selectivity for propylene [39,40]. However, Pt atoms with much higher electron density may pose a negative effect on lower alkane adsorption and C-H activation, which weakens the binding of 1-propyl to the catalyst surface and results in a higher energy barrier for propane dehydrogenation. Here, experimental kinetics studies showed that the apparent activation energy of n-butane dehydrogenation on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 was slightly higher than that on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2, indicating that kinetically the dehydrogenation of lower alkanes was favorable on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 in which Pt featured the moderate electron density. Besides the electronic states, the metal surface structure referring to the arrangements of the atoms in small metal particles is also widely considered as a crucial factor in determining the activity and selectivity of heterogeneous catalytic reactions. During the conversion of lower alkanes, cracking through C-C cleavage is considered structure sensitive as its specific rate varies with particle size, while dehydrogenation by C-H cleavage is relatively structure insensitive [41–42]. Indeed, the metal surface structure strongly depends on particle size. More unsaturated Pt atoms on small Pt NPs exhibited high activity towards cracking. In contrast, dehydrogenation favors flatter surfaces on large Pt particles with a higher proportion of terrace sites versus corners and step sites. Therefore, the conversion of lower alkane usually decreases, while the selectivity for propylene increases with increasing the size of Pt NPs. In contrast, in the present study, the addition of Sn diluted Pt NPs into small Pt NPs. Meanwhile, Pt metal surface structure was further modified by Sn species due to the induction of the coverage of Pt atoms of low coordination in the small NPs by Pt-SnO2 SMSI. The left terrace Pt sites surrounded by Sn species on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 exhibited both high activity and high selectivity for lower alkenes in the dehydrogenation of lower alkanes. The isolation of Pt was further enhanced in the case of Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 via Pt-Sn alloying. The frequency factor A in the kinetic study, which is one of the indexes reflecting the number of active sites and turnover number drastically increased on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 by a factor of 103 compared with that on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2. This indicated significant contribution of the geometric configurations of the exposed Pt atoms in Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 to its superior catalytic performance. The geometric effect of Sn makes a larger contribution than the electronic effect on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 (Scheme 3 ). 5 Conclusion The present work explained the nature of silica supported Pt–Sn bimetallic catalysts, the most important industrial catalysts currently available for lower alkene production. It was found that the catalyst structure and catalytic properties are closely related to Pt-SnO2 SMSI, which can be efficiently regulated by varying the thermal treatment atmosphere and temperature. Pt-SnO2 SMSI with different configurations can be constructed through oxidative, inert or reductive treatment. Highly dispersed Pt NPs with Pt–SnOx (x < 2) were present on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2, and Sn surface-enriched Pt–Sn alloy NPs were formed on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2. Both, especially the reductive treatment showed high catalytic activity in propane/n-butane dehydrogenation. Combining a series of characterization techniques, the geometric and electronic properties of SMSI in active Pt–Sn/SiO2catalysts, as well as their contribution to catalytic performance are disentangled. The active Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 and Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 exhibited similar particle size as Pt/SiO2_773 K H2, but the d electron density of Pt atoms was higher on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 and highest on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 than on the monometallic catalyst. This electron modification of the Pt affected C–H bond cleavage and alkene desorption, resulted in a higher apparent activation energy on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 than Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2 for n-butane dehydrogenation. Concurrently and more importantly, the addition of Sn geometrically separated the Pt NPs, generating more active and selective ensembles containing several adjacent Pt and Sn atom. The geometric modification made a larger contribution than the electronic modification of Pt to the superior dehydrogenation performance of Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2. Acknowledgement L. coredata.dc:description: The addition of tin (Sn) is commonly used as a design strategy for catalyst optimization of platinum-based catalysts. The mechanistic understanding of this class of systems is, however, obscured by the structural complexity. Herein, a series of catalyst characterization techniques including X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) and in-situ CO diffuse reflectance infrared fourier transform spectroscopy (CO-DRIFTS) were utilized to study the catalyst structure. It was found that the structure and catalytic properties are closely related with the interaction between Pt and SnO2 (specifically the Pt-SnO2 strong metal-support interaction (SMSI)), which can be continuously tuned by thermal treating the Pt-Sn/SiO2 precursor at different atmospheres and temperatures. The treatment in an oxidative atmosphere (O2) also can generate Pt-SnO2 SMSI, which became weak at higher temperatures and led to the growth of Pt nanoparticles (NPs). Pt-SnO2 SMSI became stronger when the oxygen atmosphere was changed to an inert (N2) atmosphere. Small metallic Pt NPs were formed and their dispersion was increased with increasing treatment temperature with inert gas. The catalyst presented a moderate activity in the dehydrogenation of lower alkanes. The treatment in a reductive atmosphere (H2) produced the strongest Pt-SnO2 SMSI and most active catalyst. Highly dispersed Sn surface-enriched Pt–Sn alloy NPs were formed on SiO2, in which Pt was most electron rich. The apparent activation energy in n-butane dehydrogenation is higher on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 than the corresponding one on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K N2. The kinetic studies revealed that the extreme isolation of Pt on Pt–Sn/SiO2_1073 K H2 (geometrical effects) dominantly contributed to its superior catalytic performance. The present work highlights the effects of thermal treatment-induced Pt-SnO2 SMSI, providing a new insight into the structure of Pt–Sn bimetallic catalysts and the promotional role of Sn in the dehydrogenation of lower alkanes to olefins on Pt surfaces.
coredata.dc:title: Elucidating strong metal-support interactions in Pt–Sn/SiO2 catalyst and its consequences for dehydrogenation of lower alkanes
